  <title>
   Astronomers estimate 100 billion habitable Earth-like planets in the Milky Way, 50 sextillion in the universe | ExtremeTech
  </title>
  <link href="http://www.extremetech.com/extreme/152573-astronomers-estimate-100-billion-habitable-earth-like-planets-in-the-milky-way-50-sextillion-in-the-universe" rel="canonical"/>

  <meta content="Astronomers at the University of Auckland claim that there are actually around 100 billion habitable, Earth-like planets in the Milky ..." name="description"/>
  <meta content="Astronomers estimate 100 billion habitable Earth-like planets in the Milky Way, 50 sextillion in the universe | ExtremeTech" property="og:title"/>
  <meta content="ExtremeTech" property="og:site_name"/>
  <meta content="http://www.extremetech.com/extreme/152573-astronomers-estimate-100-billion-habitable-earth-like-planets-in-the-milky-way-50-sextillion-in-the-universe" property="og:url"/>
  <meta content="Astronomers at the University of Auckland claim that there are actually around 100 billion habitable, Earth-like planets in the Milky Way. There are roughly 500 billion galaxies in the universe, meaning there is somewhere in the region of 50,000,000,000,000,000,000,000 habitable planets. I'll leave you to do the math on whether one of those 50 sextillion planets has the right conditions for nurturing life or not." property="og:description"/>
  <meta content="http://www.extremetech.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/04/Milky_Way_IR_Spitzer-cropped-smaller.jpg" property="og:image"/>
  <meta content="summary_large_image" name="twitter:card"/>
  <meta content="ExtremeTech" name="twitter:site"/>
  <meta content="@ExtremeTech" name="twitter:creator"/>
  <meta content="extremetech.com" name="twitter:domain"/>
  <meta content="Astronomers estimate 100 billion habitable Earth-like planets in the Milky Way, 50 sextillion in the universe | ExtremeTech" name="twitter:title"/>
  <meta content="http://www.extremetech.com/extreme/152573-astronomers-estimate-100-billion-habitable-earth-like-planets-in-the-milky-way-50-sextillion-in-the-universe" name="twitter:url"/>
  <meta content="Astronomers at the University of Auckland claim that there are actually around 100 billion habitable, Earth-like planets in the Milky Way. There are roughly 500 billion galaxies in the universe, meaning there is somewhere in the region of 50,000,000,000,000,000,000,000 habitable planets. I'll leave you to do the math on whether one of those 50 sextillion planets has the right conditions for nurturing life or not." name="twitter:description"/>
  <meta content="http://www.extremetech.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/04/Milky_Way_IR_Spitzer-cropped-smaller.jpg" name="twitter:image:src"/>

	                 return {};
	           }
	            url.replace(/([^?=&amp;]+)(=([^&amp;]*))?/g, function ($0, $1, $2, $3) { q[$1] = $3; });

  <link href="http://www.extremetech.com/wp-includes/wlwmanifest.xml" rel="wlwmanifest" type="application/wlwmanifest+xml"/>
  <link href="http://www.extremetech.com/gaming/152511-unreal-engine-4-looks-much-better-on-the-pc-compared-to-the-ps4" rel="prev" title="Unreal Engine 4 looks much better on the PC compared to the PS4"/>
  <link href="http://www.extremetech.com/mobile/152358-phablets-are-just-a-fad" rel="next" title="Phablets are just a fad"/>

         <style type="text/css">
          #stickybanner,

           googletag.cmd.push(function() { googletag.display('TopBanner'); });
          </script>
          <noscript>
           <a href="http://pubads.g.doubleclick.net/gampad/jump?iu=/4585/zd.extech/extremesection_ATF&amp;t=zdid%3D152573%26cmn%3Dzd&amp;sz=970x250|728x90&amp;template=article_sticky&amp;c=9367944&amp;tile=1">

     <div id="main">
      <div class="add-nav">
       <ul class="breadcrumbs" id="breadcrumbs">
        <!-- Breadcrumb NavXT 5.1.1 -->
        <li class="home">
         <a href="http://www.extremetech.com" title="Go to ExtremeTech.">
          ExtremeTech
         </a>
        </li>
        <li>
         <span typeof="v:Breadcrumb">
          <a class="taxonomy category" href="http://www.extremetech.com/category/extreme" property="v:title" rel="v:url" title="Go to the Extreme category archives.">
           Extreme
          </a>
         </span>

        <li class="current_item">
         Astronomers estimate 100 billion habitable Earth-like planets in the Milky Way, 50 sextillion in the universe
        </li>
       </ul>
      </div>
      <div class="twocolumns">
       <div id="content">
        <div class="article">
         <div class="title">
          <h2>
           Astronomers estimate 100 billion habitable Earth-like planets in the Milky Way, 50 sextillion in the universe
          </h2>
          <ul>
           <li>
            <span class="by vcard">
             By
             <a href="http://www.extremetech.com/author/santhony" rel="author" title="Posts by Sebastian Anthony">
              Sebastian Anthony
             </a>
             on April 4, 2013 at 10:23 am
            </span>
           </li>
           <li class="comments">
            <a data-disqus-identifier="152573 http://www.extremetech.com/?p=152573" href="http://www.extremetech.com/extreme/152573-astronomers-estimate-100-billion-habitable-earth-like-planets-in-the-milky-way-50-sextillion-in-the-universe#disqus_thread">
             <span>
              Comment
             </span>
            </a>
           </li>
          </ul>
         </div>
         <div class="content">
          <span id="intelliTXT" name="intellitxt">
           <img alt="The Milky Way, as seen by NASA's infrared Spitzer telescope" class="attachment-full wp-post-image" height="438" src="http://www.extremetech.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/04/Milky_Way_IR_Spitzer-cropped-smaller-640x438.jpg" width="640"/>
           <div class="photo">
            <div class="box2">
             <h3>
              Share This article
             </h3>
             <div class="addthis_sharing_toolbox">
             </div>
            </div>
           </div>
           <p>
            Astronomers at the University of Auckland claim that there are actually around 100 billion habitable, Earth-like planets in the Milky Way  significantly more than the previous estimate of around 17 billion. There are roughly 500 billion galaxies in the universe, meaning there is somewhere in the region of 50,000,000,000,000,000,000,000 (510
            <sup>
             22
            </sup>
            ) habitable planets. Ill leave you to do the math on whether one of those 50 sextillion planets has the right conditions for nurturing alien life or not.
           </p>
           <p>
            The previous figure of 17 billion Earth-like planets in the Milky Way came from theHarvard-Smithsonian Center for Astrophysics in January, which analyzed data from the Kepler space observatory. Kepler essentially measures the dimming (apparent magnitude) of stars as planets transit in front of them  the more a star dims, the larger the planet. Through repeated observations we can work out the planets orbital period, from which we can usually derive the orbital distance and surface temperature. According to Phil Yock from the University of Auckland, Keplers technique generally finds Earth-sized planets that are quite close to parent stars, and are therefore generally hotter than Earth [and not habitable].
           </p>
           <p>
            The University of Aucklands technique, called gravitational microlensing, instead measures the number of Earth-size planets that orbit at twice the Sun-Earth distance. This results in a list of planets that are generally cooler than Earth  but by interpolating between this new list, and Keplers list, the Kiwi astronomers hope to generate a more accurate list of habitable, Earth-like planets. We anticipate a number in the order of 100 billion, says Yock.
           </p>
           <p>
            <a href="http://www.extremetech.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/04/Gravitational_lens-full.jpg">
             <img alt="Gravitational microlensing" class="alignnone size-large wp-image-152574" height="484" src="http://www.extremetech.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/04/Gravitational_lens-full-640x484.jpg" width="640"/>
            </a>
           </p>
           <p>
            Gravitational microlensing, an effect theorized by Einstein back in 1936, is exactly what it sounds like. Essentially, light emitted by a star is bent by the gravity of massive objects, ultimately allowing astronomers to work out just how large those objects are. Gravitational microlensing has been used in recent years to detect planets the size of Neptune or Jupiter, and now Yock his colleagues at the University of Auckland have proposed a new method for detecting Earth-sized planets. The astronomers hope to use this new microlensing technique with a huge suite of telescopes  located in Chile, South Africa, Australia, New Zealand, Hawaii, and Texas  to confirm their estimate of 100 billion Earth-like habitable planets.
           </p>
           <p>
            Suffice it to say, if the Milky Way contains 100 billion Earth-like planets, and theres somewhere in the region of 500 billion galaxies, then theres an extremely high chance of other planets harboring life. As for
            <em>
             how
            </em>
            well get to those planets, though  or, alternatively, how the residents of those planets will get to us  remains a very big question. The nearest probably-habitable planet isTau Ceti e, which is 11.9 light years from Earth. The fastest spacecraft ever, Helios II, traveled at 43 miles per second (70km/s), or0.000234
            <em>
             c
            </em>
            (the speed of light). At that speed it would take
            <em>
             51,000 years
            </em>
            for a spacecraft to reach Tau Ceti e.
           </p>
           <div class="wp-caption alignright" id="attachment_136416" style="width: 310px">
            <a href="http://www.extremetech.com/wp-content/uploads/2012/09/warp_drive_starship.jpeg">
             <img alt="Harold White's possible warp drive, and star ship" class="size-medium wp-image-136416" height="165" src="http://www.extremetech.com/wp-content/uploads/2012/09/warp_drive_starship-300x165.jpeg" width="300"/>
            </a>
            <p class="wp-caption-text">
             Harold Whites possible Alcubierre warp drive, and star ship
            </p>
           </div>
           <p>
            It gets worse: Helios II was only travelling that fast because it was orbiting close to the Sun; Voyager, for example, travels at just 8 miles per second (so, about 200,000 years to reach Tau Ceti e). To reach another star within a reasonable time period (say, 50-100 years) we would need a propulsion system thats capable of around 0.1
            <em>
             c
            </em>
            (10% light speed). There are a few proposed methods for reaching such insane speeds (antimatter rockets, fusion rockets), but nothing thats being immediately (and seriously) considered for interstellar travel. Who knows, maybe
            <a href="http://www.extremetech.com/extreme/136408-nasa-working-on-faster-than-light-travel-says-warp-drives-are-plausible">
             NASAs warp drive
            </a>
            will pan out? If they can work out the whole
            <a href="http://www.extremetech.com/extreme/140635-the-downside-of-warp-drives-annihilating-whole-star-systems-when-you-arrive">
             annihilating-the-star-system-upon-arrival issue
            </a>
            , that is
           </p>
           <p>
            Research paper:
            <a href="http://mnras.oxfordjournals.org/content/early/2013/03/26/mnras.stt318">
             doi:10.1093/mnras/stt318
            </a>
             Extending the planetary mass function to Earth mass by microlensing at moderately high magnification
           </p>
           <p>
            <em>
             [The image at the top of the story is an infrared image of the core of the Milky Way, captured by NASA's Spitzer space telescope. Infrared imaging allows you to see many stars which are normally obscured by intergalactic dust.]
            </em>
           </p>
          </span>
         </div>
         <div class="articles-list">
          <div class="holder">
           <div class="widget column widget_execphp" id="execphp-45">
            <div data-page-type="article" data-placement="Below Article Thumbnails - Article -gtd" id="taboola-below-article-thumbnails">
            </div>
            <script type="text/javascript">
             window._taboola = window._taboola || [];
      _taboola.push({
        mode: 'thumbnails-a',
        container: 'taboola-below-article-thumbnails',
        placement: 'Below Article Thumbnails - Article -gtd',
        target_type: 'mix'
      });
            </script>
            <div data-page-type="article" data-placement="Below Article Text Links - Article -gtd" id="taboola-below-article-text-links">
            </div>
            <script type="text/javascript">
             window._taboola = window._taboola || [];
      _taboola.push({
        mode: 'hybrid-text-links-a',

        placement: 'Below Article Text Links - Article -gtd',
        target_type: 'mix'
      });
            </script>
           </div>
          </div>
         </div>
        </div>
        <div class="articles-list">
         <div class="holder">

          </div>
          <div class="widget column widget_disquswidget" id="disquswidget-3">
           <script type="text/javascript">
            var disqus_developer = 1;
           </script>
           <div class="title">
            <span class="count">
             <a href="#disqus_thread">
              Comment
             </a>
            </span>
            <h3>
             Post a Comment
            </h3>
           </div>
           <div id="disqus_thread">
            <div id="dsq-content">
             <ul id="dsq-comments">
              <li class="comment even thread-even depth-1" id="dsq-comment-142141">
               <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-142141">
                <cite id="dsq-cite-142141">
                 <span id="dsq-author-user-142141">
                  Sipho Mfungi
                 </span>
                </cite>
               </div>
               <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-142141">
                <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-142141">
                 <p>
                  is it not a stretch to claim that a planet is habitable just by measuring a dimming effect on a star?
                 </p>
                </div>
               </div>
               <ul class="children">
                <li class="comment odd alt depth-2" id="dsq-comment-142297">
                 <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-142297">
                  <cite id="dsq-cite-142297">
                   <span id="dsq-author-user-142297">
                    some_guy_said
                   </span>
                  </cite>
                 </div>
                 <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-142297">
                  <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-142297">
                   <p>
                    It would be a stretch, if they had said habitable in this article.  But they did not.
                   </p>
                   <p>
                    Earth-like is a misnomer.  It just means an earth sized planet in a certain zone around a star.  It has nothing to do with the actual planetary conditions or whether it has life on it or not.
                   </p>
                  </div>
                 </div>
                 <ul class="children">
                  <li class="comment even depth-3" id="dsq-comment-142695">
                   <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-142695">
                    <cite id="dsq-cite-142695">
                     http://www.facebook.com/brandon.holt.31
                     <span id="dsq-author-user-142695">
                      Brandon Holt
                     </span>
                    </cite>
                   </div>
                   <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-142695">
                    <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-142695">
                     <p>
                      It did say habitable, though. Multiple times. Though I think you are right and Earth like is what was actually meant.
                     </p>
                    </div>
                   </div>
                   <ul class="children">
                    <li class="comment odd alt depth-4" id="dsq-comment-142981">

                       </span>
                      </cite>
                     </div>
                     <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-142981">

                       <p>
                        Im not sure why I couldnt word search it correctly.  Maybe I word searched with space?  I stand corrected.
                       </p>
                      </div>
                     </div>
                    </li>
                    <!-- #comment-## -->

              <!-- #comment-## -->
              <li class="comment even thread-odd thread-alt depth-1" id="dsq-comment-142144">
               <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-142144">
                <cite id="dsq-cite-142144">
                 <span id="dsq-author-user-142144">
                  VirtualMark
                 </span>
                </cite>
               </div>
               <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-142144">
                <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-142144">
                 <p>
                  Either warp drive, slow moving generation ships or suspended animation is needed!  Imo its one of the most important things to the survival of our species.
                 </p>
                 <p>
                  100 billion planets in the Milky Way alone!  Thats a lot of planets for us to explore, and god only knows what creatures theyll have on them.
                 </p>
                 <p>
                  Although at the moment it seems a bit of a stretch to say 100 billion  we just need to find ONE!  And then  we still need to find some form of life.  Its frustrating to know that the chances of life are so huge, yet we have found absolutely nothing.
                 </p>
                </div>
               </div>
               <ul class="children">
                <li class="comment odd alt depth-2" id="dsq-comment-142181">
                 <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-142181">
                  <cite id="dsq-cite-142181">
                   http://www.facebook.com/evgeni.bykarskij
                   <span id="dsq-author-user-142181">
                    Evgeni Bykarskij
                   </span>
                  </cite>
                 </div>
                 <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-142181">
                  <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-142181">
                   <p>
                    Actually, the most important thing  to the survival of our spieces is to behave ourselves right here  on Earth
                   </p>
                  </div>
                 </div>
                 <ul class="children">
                  <li class="comment even depth-3" id="dsq-comment-142210">
                   <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-142210">
                    <cite id="dsq-cite-142210">
                     <span id="dsq-author-user-142210">
                      VirtualMark
                     </span>
                    </cite>
                   </div>
                   <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-142210">
                    <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-142210">
                     <p>
                      Yes, of course.  And what do you suggest we do after our population grows?  Of course, we could have WW3, which would probably leave a large part of the Earth uninhabitable, but the population would be reduced.
                     </p>
                     <p>
                      Or we can live peacefully, procreate and then run into resource problems.  So, whats your suggestion when resources become this limited?  When we have billions more to feed than we have now?
                     </p>
                     <p>
                      And of theres the constant threat of a natural disaster, a global extinction event such as a gamma ray burst from a nearby star  what do you suggest we do to counter that threat?
                     </p>
                     <p>
                      Mine would be to look for a second home.
                     </p>
                    </div>
                   </div>

                      <!-- #comment-## -->
                      <li class="comment odd alt depth-5" id="dsq-comment-142273">
                       <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-142273">
                        <cite id="dsq-cite-142273">
                         <span id="dsq-author-user-142273">
                          VirtualMark
                         </span>
                        </cite>
                       </div>
                       <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-142273">
                        <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-142273">
                         <p>
                          Well to be honest, Im not exactly talking about the near future.  Im talking about many decades, probably many centuries ahead here  when we have the technology to travel between stars.  I like to be positive, but Im pretty sure that we wont see interstellar travel in our lifetimes.
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          Most people dont understand just how difficult it is, the distances are just so insanely huge!  Theyre beyond human comprehension, which is why we use easy numbers like 10 light years, it doesnt sound as bad then.  And 10 light years is literally right on our doorstep in astronomical terms.  Our galaxy alone is 100,000 light years across, its crazy!
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          So yeah, Im not talking about any immediate solutions here, more of a distant future of humanity.  And thats if we survive our early years here  were still babies compared to the age of the Earth.
                         </p>
                        </div>
                       </div>
                      </li>
                      <!-- #comment-## -->
                      <li class="comment even depth-5" id="dsq-comment-142679">
                       <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-142679">
                        <cite id="dsq-cite-142679">
                         <span id="dsq-author-user-142679">
                          WerrydaleTed
                         </span>
                        </cite>
                       </div>
                       <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-142679">
                        <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-142679">
                         <p>
                          Earth is the only inhabited planet in all of space!  We are a created species in a created universe and have not arisen by random chance. The mathematical chances of life arising spontaneously, that is without being created by intelligence is a big fat zero. Life is far, far too complicated. There is no evidence in the Bible that God created life anywhere else but here.  So, finding a planet with life is impossible and without life you have to terraform a suitable planet which could take thousands of years.  We have no science that can get us to another planet anyway.
                          <br/>
                          Oh by the way sending fuel on ahead is futile.  It too would have to accelerate to extreme velocites which would use up all its fuel.  Any fuel tanks would be empty by the time you got there.  Rendezvousing with anything containing fuel would be impossible if the speeds are not matched almost exactly. Then you cannot catch it if you are not going faster.  From very high relativistic speeds one cannot afford to slow down as it would require huge amounts of fuel. Then you have to burn even more to regain speed.  To summarize, catch a high speed fuel depot running at very high speed would require the enormours use of fuel to slow down to retrieve fuel from an empty vessel.  Hopeless.
                          <br/>
                          By the way, there is no population problem on this earth. All of the westernized societies have declining populations (except by immigration), except for the Muslims who are not really our friends,if you get the point.
                         </p>
                        </div>
                       </div>
                      </li>

                    <li class="comment even depth-4" id="dsq-comment-142229">

                       <span id="dsq-author-user-142229">
                        Joel Detrow
                       </span>
                      </cite>
                     </div>
                     <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-142229">
                      <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-142229">
                       <p>
                        Its a known fact that as education and contraceptive availability improve, families have fewer children. A slightly optimistic estimate for the stable ceiling population of the planet is 10 billion, and we already grow enough food to feed 11 billion. Population will only be an issue if education is ignored.
                       </p>
                       <p>
                        Honestly, the only problem I foresee is an era where antibiotics have ceased to be effective because we use them so much. That could really be dangerous for the connected society we live in today.
                       </p>
                      </div>

                      <!-- #comment-## -->
                      <li class="comment even depth-5" id="dsq-comment-142901">
                       <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-142901">
                        <cite id="dsq-cite-142901">
                         <span id="dsq-author-user-142901">
                          George E Moss
                         </span>
                        </cite>
                       </div>
                       <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-142901">
                        <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-142901">
                         <p>
                          Who is to say we are immortal? Well, during our 20 years of the groups weekly seance meetings I have had the privilege of speaking with many who continue their living in spirit and one from Angelic Realms  he is our groups guide and teacher. One notary from spirit was Rudolf Steiner  he certainly says so, and is. All conversations are on our website, mentioned earlier. But let me provide a statement received from our Angelic Guide on 11th Dec 2000 in reply to a question concerning Dalai Lama incarnations:
                          <br/>
                          ~ Yes, I have told you there are many Masters who walk this planet and let us firstly say this to you: that those who have attained such knowledge have the ability to realize and understand spiritual ways.  The gentleman you speak of has indeed reincarnated many, many times in order that the teaching may continue.  It is, in fact, many different aspects of his soul.  It is not the same aspect each time, of course, but it is felt that, when one has reached such attunement between the physical world and our world, that that attunement must continue for the benefit of all who come into contact with him and of course for his own souls growth.  Do not doubt that by whichever name he reincarnates with, it is still many aspects of the one soul.
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          Reincarnation is the norm for this planet as on all the others of this universe, and the soul has immortality. There is much evidence, and just occasionally, one who is born afresh has some degree of past life memory  I could name a few.
                         </p>
                        </div>
                       </div>
                      </li>
                      <!-- #comment-## -->
                      <li class="comment odd alt depth-5" id="dsq-comment-142908">

                         </p>

                      <!-- #comment-## -->
                      <li class="comment even depth-5" id="dsq-comment-142940">
                       <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-142940">
                        <cite id="dsq-cite-142940">
                         <span id="dsq-author-user-142940">
                          George E Moss
                         </span>
                        </cite>
                       </div>
                       <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-142940">
                        <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-142940">
                         <p>
                          Good questions! Normally when we reincarnate, the slate is wiped clean because past learning is with parent soul and we are now here for further separate purpose. Here is a para from my new book in preparation:
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          There is so much more to existence than just the one Earth life; of this there should be no doubt whatsoever. We have all been here before, but for vast majority, all direct memory of previous lives is erased. This is the regular system, but just occasionally one slips through with some degree of retained memorysufficient for proof that this is so. As a child, James Leininger for example, in 2001 at the age of three, knew all about the WWII Corsair aircraftthey get flat tyres from heavy flight deck landings, he knew the difference between a bomb and a drop tank and named the carrier Natoma Bay that he had flown from on the day he was shot down in 1945, near Iwo Jimaand he has experienced the childhood nightmares about all that.
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          Anne Frank, who died in a prison camp in 1945 was re-born nine years later in Sweden. At age three Barbro told her parents that her real name was Anne Frank. When the family visited Amsterdam, she at age ten, led them to the old house where they had lived in the war years etc. There are young souls and older souls, and souls are not confined to just the one planet; and its a big universe out there!
                         </p>
                        </div>
                       </div>
                      </li>
                      <!-- #comment-## -->
                      <li class="comment odd alt depth-5" id="dsq-comment-142944">
                       <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-142944">
                        <cite id="dsq-cite-142944">
                         <span id="dsq-author-user-142944">
                          VirtualMark
                         </span>
                        </cite>
                       </div>
                       <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-142944">
                        <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-142944">
                         <p>
                          I saw an interesting video where a young boy had claimed hed died in Scotland.  He remembers falling, then waking up as a child.  They went to visit the place  the house was there as hed described, but the people were different.  Very strange indeed.  I wondered if there is some truth in multiverse theories  maybe hed died in a parallel universe and woke up here.  But thats a lot to swallow!  The fact is that hed remembered a lot of information that was true, theres no way a boy could have imagined that house, he was in another country.
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          The thing that I dont understand  if you retain memory of a previous life, when do you remember it?  Surely if youre in your mothers womb, youre considered alive?  So when do the memories of a past life appear into your present life?  It doesnt make any sense whatsoever.
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          Another point  as you say the universe is a big place.  So big that it goes way way beyond the comprehension of any human!  And the chances of Ann Frank being reincarnated on the same planet are infinitesimally small.
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          Like I say, Id never disregard any unknown things like this, but Im also sceptical as there are so many unanswered questions.
                         </p>
                        </div>
                       </div>
                      </li>
                      <!-- #comment-## -->
                      <li class="comment even depth-5" id="dsq-comment-143101">
                       <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-143101">
                        <cite id="dsq-cite-143101">
                         <span id="dsq-author-user-143101">
                          George E Moss
                         </span>
                        </cite>
                       </div>
                       <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-143101">
                        <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-143101">
                         <p>
                          Well, I have some answers, not all. The multi-universe exists  thats a certainty that also agrees with recent scientific deduction. I think they are coincident and involve different energies (or wavelengths is acceptable thinking). In an exercise arranged from spirit, our group individuals were each overshadowed by beings from different universes, and we were able to describe how we felt! In fact, in our lives, there is much influence from those in spirit; depending on how open we are. I do not know of the Scottish event, and will just comment that sometimes, as with certain dreams, the interactions require interpretation.
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          When and how past life memory emerges depends on so many factors. Triggers with circumstance are sometimes involved. On a spiritually much-more-evolved planet that we know, there are much stronger connections. The physical beings converse freely with loved ones long after their death, also with their young before birth. On Earth, we are not that far advanced and these things occasionally happen but are not the norm.
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          Humankind reincarnates to its known planet Earth, but this is not mandatory. As we become more aware of and seek the companionship of other sentient beings, there develops the option of interplanetary incarnations. Finally, a quote from our guide Salumet in reply to a question about the future of mankind:
                          <br/>
                          ~ (14th July 1997): Why should you confine your hopes, your wishes, to the population of this planet? My wish for you would be, that you could become more aware, more universally aware, more cosmically aware, rather than stay in the confines of Earthly populationI want you my dear friends to be children of the cosmos, because that is what you are. I would wish that you can grow enough whilst we are together, to realize that what you are, and what you have been, is spirit which has been confined to one planet in this lifetime. We have spoken much about this, but now the time is coming, when all of your population, all peoples, no matter what color, what race, what religion; all will come to the realization, that we belong to the much wider scheme of life, of living, of love, of that eternal energy to which we all belong.
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          So the future and how we progress, goes hand-in-hand with our own opening up to spirit (and that includes the spiritual science way of thinking, which opens the door to many possibilities).
                         </p>
                        </div>
                       </div>
                      </li>
                      <!-- #comment-## -->
                     </ul>
                     <!-- .children -->
                    </li>

                       </p>
                       <p>
                        Anyhow Im absolutely game into seriously looking for a second home. We dont even need warp drives, with fusion rockets (not so far from our current technology) humankind will be able to jump from inhabitable system to inhabitable system.
                       </p>

                      <li class="comment even depth-5" id="dsq-comment-142252">

                       <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-142252">
                        <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-142252">
                         <p>
                          Sorry, but nuclear doesnt even begin to cut it.  Antimatter is a much more powerful fuel, and even then were talking decades to accelerate to a decent speed.  If we want to be able to travel within a human lifetime, we need to find a way to warp space.  Unless we find another way to suspend the life of a person, or extend their life many times.
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          Anyhow  this article on NASA explains the problem with nuclear power:
                          <a href="http://www.nasa.gov/centers/glenn/technology/warp/scales.html" rel="nofollow">
                           http://www.nasa.gov/centers/glenn/technology/warp/scales.html

                      <!-- #comment-## -->
                      <li class="comment odd alt depth-5" id="dsq-comment-142390">
                       <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-142390">
                        <cite id="dsq-cite-142390">
                         http://www.facebook.com/marc.guillotpuig
                         <span id="dsq-author-user-142390">
                          Marc Guillot Puig
                         </span>
                        </cite>
                       </div>
                       <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-142390">
                        <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-142390">
                         <p>
                          Project Daedalus said that we can travel at 0.12 c using fusion power. That could be enough.
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Project_Daedalus" rel="nofollow">
                           http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Project_Daedalus
                          </a>
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          By the way, we dont need to carry all the fuel. We can send fuel containers several decades in advance, and synchronize them to meet our manned flight. We can also send a robotic spaceship in a century flight, with all the necessary to start a colony at its arrival (frozen fertilized ovums, artificial uterus, and all the facilities needed to robotically raise the first generation of colons).
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          PS: Antimatter is a much more powerful fuel, indeed, but we dont know if we will ever be able to use it (create enough antimatter, contain it, ), while we are very near to master fusion power.
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          I believe that we already can start working with what we currently have, or almost have.
                         </p>
                        </div>
                       </div>

                      <li class="comment even depth-5" id="dsq-comment-142405">

                         </span>
                        </cite>
                       </div>
                       <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-142405">
                        <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-142405">
                         <p>
                          Clearly you still havent read the article.  The 1970s Project Daedalus is mentioned on the third page.
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          If you wish to base all of your ideas and knowledge on 1970s research, that is up to you.  I dont mean to be rude, but I dont like to discuss rudimentary stuff like this  I honestly dont think you have a clue what youre saying.  Unless of course  you can explain:
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          1)  How get a thousand supertankers of nuclear fuel.
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          2)  How to hoist all of this fuel into space.
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          3)  How to use your method of sending fuel ahead  I really dont think youve thought about this.  The NASA article was based on a 900 year journey, also based on continuously accelerating.  So wed also need to accelerate the fuel to get it out far enough  and then wed need to find a way to pick it up  you dont think that a spaceship hitting a supertanker of fuel at 1000s of mph could cause any problems?
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          Like I said, Ive tried to explain and also shown you an article written by some of the best scientists in the world, but you seem to prefer your own imagination and lack of understanding to actually reading the facts.
                         </p>
                        </div>
                       </div>
                      </li>
                      <!-- #comment-## -->
                      <li class="comment odd alt depth-5" id="dsq-comment-142420">
                       <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-142420">
                        <cite id="dsq-cite-142420">
                         http://www.facebook.com/marc.guillotpuig
                         <span id="dsq-author-user-142420">
                          Marc Guillot Puig
                         </span>
                        </cite>
                       </div>
                       <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-142420">
                        <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-142420">
                         <p>
                          Okay, found it :).
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          The only criticism there to Project Daedalus is that micro fusion explosions are tricky, but that inertial confinement fusion is exactly what projects like NIF are currently achieving. More interesting are inertial electrostatic confinement (a very much simpler way to achieve the same goal).
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          <a href="http://www.extremetech.com/extreme/143026-fusion-power-at-home-or-how-small-science-will-defeat-big-science" rel="nofollow">
                           http://www.extremetech.com/extreme/143026-fusion-power-at-home-or-how-small-science-will-defeat-big-science
                          </a>
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          Obviously the NASA article considers a fusion nuclear pulse rocket. Thats easy to build but very very inefficient. I know that we are not still there to use inertial confinement fusion, but we are almost there. Its only a question of decades, on the other hand we dont even know if antimatter engines or warp drives will be ever feasible.
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          About sending fuel ahead. Come on, we have plenty of experience about refueling on-flight. We only have to match speeds. Carefully planning an schedule we can send the fuel with enough time to reach the meeting point and speed at a very low acceleration (burning little fuel).
                         </p>
                        </div>
                       </div>
                      </li>
                      <!-- #comment-## -->

                      <li class="comment even depth-5" id="dsq-comment-142583">
                       <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-142583">
                        <cite id="dsq-cite-142583">
                         <span id="dsq-author-user-142583">
                          Bojwon
                         </span>
                        </cite>
                       </div>
                       <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-142583">
                        <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-142583">
                         <p>
                          Warping space would, I believe, allow for almost instantaneous travel to point B, meaning no suspension of life would be necessary. But, I would ask, if we were to travel such insane distances, wouldnt we want to travel to some planet that logically had life, not just to one that COULD sustain life? Although we now estimate there are 100 billion earth-like planets in the Milky Way, we have absolutely NO indications there is intelligent life anywhere else in this universe. SETI has yet to discover a single shred of evidence to suggest otherwise.
                         </p>
                        </div>
                       </div>
                      </li>

                       <p>
                        Hi! VirtualMark  I like your style of thinking. But of course it is PHYSICAL thinking. Thats okay, we all have much of that. Answers and clarity come from within and from spirit (as with the true seer Nostradamus!). I and our group receive via seance meetings (see
                        <a href="http://www.salumetandfriends.org" rel="nofollow">
                         http://www.salumetandfriends.org
                        </a>
                        , scientific inquiry page might be a good start). WW 3 will not happen. We seem to have moved beyond that. Resources can be plentiful if we put our minds to that. I was nine at the start of WW 2 and so have had a few years to grapple with these seemingly imponderables!
                       </p>
                      </div>
                     </div>
                     <ul class="children">
                      <li class="comment even depth-5" id="dsq-comment-142887">
                       <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-142887">
                        <cite id="dsq-cite-142887">
                         <span id="dsq-author-user-142887">
                          VirtualMark
                         </span>
                        </cite>
                       </div>
                       <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-142887">
                        <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-142887">
                         <p>
                          Hi, thanks for the reply.  While I respect your beliefs, I also respect hard facts and evidence.  Ive heard many claims about things that have absolutely no proof in the physical world  ghosts, UFOs, gods etc.  And while I would never say that they cant exist, I also dont like to just pretend that they do.  The problem is that in my whole life I have not seen one single supernatural event!  Ever.
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          And believe me, I want to.   If I saw a ghost or an act of god that Id be very happy as it would be proof of life after death or another spiritual world.  In a way, we could say that the universe itself is proof of god, as there appears to be intelligent design everywhere we look in nature.  I just dont want to jump the gun.  One thing I really dont like about religion is the stupidity that follows it  people believing in a book that is clearly written by men to control people.  But I also dont like atheists  they are too quick to disregard the possibility of a god.
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          Youve been around a lot longer than I have, and as you say youve had a lot longer to ponder these questions!  But from all of your years of seances  have you had any actual inspirations that have lead to practical real world uses?  Such as a scientific discovery or some future knowledge?
                         </p>
                        </div>
                       </div>
                      </li>
                      <!-- #comment-## -->
                      <li class="comment odd alt depth-5" id="dsq-comment-142909">
                       <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-142909">
                        <cite id="dsq-cite-142909">
                         <span id="dsq-author-user-142909">
                          George E Moss
                         </span>
                        </cite>
                       </div>
                       <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-142909">
                        <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-142909">
                         <p>
                          I still like your style of thinking and you are right to question everything. So much published data is rubbish! The hardest of EVIDENCE of things beyond our science and technology are the earliest and best pyramids. Why were they built and by whom? Bear in mind that the Bosnian Pyramid of the Sun has been radio-carbon dated to &gt;30,000 years. They were built by visiting ETs for purpose of producing energy (by sweeping through the aether with Earth rotation) to sustain them whilst here and to power their return flight. Russian scientists have done great work making glass-fiber pyramids and demonstrating energy production and properties.
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          Most of us are not sufficiently developed psychically to be able to see ghosts (residual energies from past events). We have three quite strongly psychic and clairvoyant ones in the group, and it has been interesting when they have been aware of the same thing and compare notes  a kind of proof when two can see the same thing  even during our interplanetary communications!
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          When I speak of spirituality; this is what lies beyond the formal religions. The latter are very imperfect stepping stones towards this and very big mistakes have been made. The formal religions have nearly had their day. More advanced planets know and have developed spirituality; and all ET beings that we know recognize the one Creative Principle of this and other universes. Now thats a big statement  I wonder how it rests with you?
                         </p>
                        </div>
                       </div>
                      </li>

                <li class="comment even depth-2" id="dsq-comment-142296">
                 <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-142296">
                  <cite id="dsq-cite-142296">
                   <span id="dsq-author-user-142296">
                    some_guy_said
                   </span>
                  </cite>
                 </div>
                 <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-142296">
                  <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-142296">
                   <p>
                    Im pretty sure when they say earth-like, that it would actually include planets like mars and venus.  Basically, it only means an earth sized planet in the goldilocks zone.
                   </p>
                   <p>
                    That does not mean that it actually has a temperate climate with life on it.  The conditions for life as we know it are actually pretty specific.
                   </p>
                   <p>
                    The fermi paradox is retarded.  If an advanced civilization put out a single broad signal with as much power as the entire human civilization can harness from the NEAREST STAR, we would not be able to detect it.  The idea that a super advanced civilization would communicate across stars the same way we do with radio waves is absolutely ludicrous.  If there was absolutely no other way to communicate, even sending an actual person on a ship would be more practical and feasible.
                   </p>
                   <p>
                    So, earthlike life is not necessarily common or prolific.  Detecting/communicating with civilizations is not likely to occur during our lifetimes.
                   </p>
                   <p>
                    However, detecting a planet overrun with earthlike plant life or earthlike conditions through spectral analysis  That almost definitely will happen while we are still alive.  So we do have something to look forward to.
                   </p>
                  </div>
                 </div>
                 <ul class="children">
                  <li class="comment odd alt depth-3" id="dsq-comment-142304">
                   <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-142304">
                    <cite id="dsq-cite-142304">
                     <span id="dsq-author-user-142304">
                      VirtualMark
                     </span>
                    </cite>
                   </div>
                   <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-142304">
                    <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-142304">
                     <p>
                      This is true  I read that wed need an antennae roughly the size of the distance from Earth to Mars to be able to pick up a radio signal from a neighbouring star.  And thats with analog transmission  digital is many times harder to detect, and in the short time weve had radio(less than 100 years) weve already switched to digital.
                     </p>
                     <p>
                      Although  we dont know what future technologies will bring  we may find new ways to pick up weaker signals.
                     </p>
                     <p>
                      Yeah I read science news every day in the hope that we find another Earth.  Like you say  without spectral analysis it could just be another Venus or Mars, pretty useless for our needs.  But Im sure with future generations of telescopes well get some good results.  Even optical images will be feasible with next gen telescopes!
                     </p>
                    </div>
                   </div>
                  </li>
                  <!-- #comment-## -->
                 </ul>
                 <!-- .children -->
                </li>
                <!-- #comment-## -->
               </ul>
               <!-- .children -->
              </li>

              <li class="comment odd alt thread-even depth-1" id="dsq-comment-142612">
               <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-142612">
                <cite id="dsq-cite-142612">
                 <span id="dsq-author-user-142612">
                  Mike Morrissey
                 </span>
                </cite>
               </div>
               <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-142612">
                <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-142612">
                 <p>
                  Move?? Not!!  None of us would live long enough to make a contribution. The cost per pound to get there and survive . think about it.               <!-- #comment-## -->
              <li class="comment even thread-odd thread-alt depth-1" id="dsq-comment-142616">
               <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-142616">
                <cite id="dsq-cite-142616">
                 <span id="dsq-author-user-142616">
                  Herbaceous
                 </span>
                </cite>
               </div>
               <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-142616">
                <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-142616">
                 <p>
                  It always makes me giggle when people think we can just pop to another planet and set up camp.
                 </p>
                 <p>
                  Its taken billions of years for life to evolve here on Earth (unless you believe in the Garden of Eden), and each form of life has had to adapt to its environment, overcome conflict (with disease etc.) and finally be strong enough to sustain itself.
                 </p>
                 <p>
                  Just like in the famous War of the Worlds, theres, likely, no chance we would ever simply be able to inhabit another planet, due to the chance of being incompatible with its ecosystem.
                 </p>
                 <p>
                  Or worse, we screw up the balance and destroy another planet in our wake :P
                 </p>
                 <p>
                  Lets just take care of what weve got here :)
                 </p>
                </div>
               </div>
              </li>
              <!-- #comment-## -->

              <!-- #comment-## -->
              <li class="comment even thread-odd thread-alt depth-1" id="dsq-comment-142656">
               <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-142656">
                <cite id="dsq-cite-142656">
                 <span id="dsq-author-user-142656">
                  LeoH
                 </span>
                </cite>
               </div>
               <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-142656">
                <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-142656">
                 <p>
                  Although my first impulse is to also say, we need to take care of the
                  <br/>
                  planet we have, even if that WAS possible, were still too many on the
                  <br/>
                  planet in order TO take care of this planet without any increase in the
                  <br/>
                  number of responsible humans.  Looking for new real estate is
                  <br/>
                  something were decades behind the curve in doing.
                 </p>
                 <p>
                  Its
                  <br/>
                  interesting to notice my change in feeling about SF from when I first
                  <br/>
                  read about travel to other worlds and colonies.  Then I was excited
                  <br/>
                  about it, now looking around I see what humans do and have done to new
                  <br/>
                  lands and lifeforms, all through historic time.  I am not as excited or
                  <br/>
                  positive about humans going to other worlds now.  All I can think about
                  <br/>
                  are the Europeans and the Native Americans and how that interaction went
                  <br/>
                  down.   Now we have racism, litter, pollution as an expected part of
                  <br/>
                  our environment. I have no delusion it wouldnt happen in any future
                  <br/>
                  with alien life and humans.
                 </p>
                </div>
               </div>
              </li>
              <!-- #comment-## -->
              <li class="comment odd alt thread-even depth-1" id="dsq-comment-142670">
               <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-142670">
                <cite id="dsq-cite-142670">
                 <span id="dsq-author-user-142670">
                  Openmind
                 </span>
                </cite>
               </div>
               <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-142670">
                <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-142670">
                 <p>
                  Most of the earlier posts seem to contemplate humans travelling to another planet for one of two reasons:
                  <br/>
                  a) to escape overcrowding as population growth makes life on earth intolerable, by discovering new lands to settle,
                  <br/>
                  b) to save the species from extinction when the earth can no longer support life.
                 </p>
                 <p>
                  Both are ultimately pointless. a) because, as has been mentioned, only a tiny fraction of the population would fit on the spaceship ark. Those remaining here would continue to multiply until numbers until some natural limit is reached. Those remaining behind would therefore see no benefit, whilst those on the ark wouldnt either, as, even at the most optimistic speed, the journey would last for several generations at least. The distant descendants who might eventually arrive at the new home (which will probably be uninhabitable anyway, will have no direct memory of what was left behind.
                 </p>
                 <p>
                  As for b), what reason is there for saving our species? Millions of species have become extinct during earths history, whats so special about homo sapiens? If we are really so arrogant about ourselves that we have to find a way to continue after doomsday, it doesnt need to involve aiming a clumsy giant spaceship at a distant star and hoping for the best. Homo Sapiens can be reduced to a genetic code that can be filed on a computer, to be projected into space and resurrected by robots when a suitable environment is found. Not possible now, but with a billion or two years to work on the problem before the earth is fried, scientists ought to be able to come up with something.
                 </p>
                </div>
               </div>
               <ul class="children">
                <li class="comment even depth-2" id="dsq-comment-143897">
                 <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-143897">
                  <cite id="dsq-cite-143897">
                   <span id="dsq-author-user-143897">
                    4th wright
                   </span>
                  </cite>
                 </div>
                 <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-143897">
                  <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-143897">
                   <p>
                    I agree with most of your points, especially our arrogance, but I think our species has a responsibility to propagate itself to the best of its ability. What if we are the only sentient beings? (Not that I think we are, but  WHERE IS EVERYBODY??)
                   </p>
                   <p>
                    My family once lived in Europe. Three generations ago they came to America. Im an American, but I still cherish my Italian roots. I think the same would be true of a generational ark. Upon their arrival, they would not be Earthlings, but they would (hopefully) still be human, and there is no reason they could not carry with them the wisdom and history of their home planet (if for no other reason than to avoid making the same mistakes).
                   </p>
                  </div>
                 </div>
                </li>
                <!-- #comment-## -->
               </ul>
               <!-- .children -->
              </li>
              <!-- #comment-## -->
              <li class="comment odd alt thread-odd thread-alt depth-1" id="dsq-comment-142776">
               <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-142776">
                <cite id="dsq-cite-142776">
                 <span id="dsq-author-user-142776">
                  reter113
                 </span>
                </cite>
               </div>
               <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-142776">
                <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-142776">
                 <p>
                  When people have killed our earth, they 100 billion other ones to go to.
                 </p>
                </div>
               </div>
              </li>
              <!-- #comment-## -->
              <li class="comment even thread-even depth-1" id="dsq-comment-142802">
               <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-142802">
                <cite id="dsq-cite-142802">
                 <span id="dsq-author-user-142802">
                  George E Moss
                 </span>
                </cite>
               </div>
               <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-142802">
                <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-142802">
                 <p>
                  True, there are many habitable planets. There is no need to postulate or to dream of physically visiting other beings when we can simply mind-link and communicate with ETs. Mind is external to space-time and is not subject to space-time rules. Our seance group has communicated INSTANTANEOUSLY with others and brain behaves as a biological computer that downloads the thought-behind-words to its known language. See our website
                  <a href="http://www.salumetandfriends.org" rel="nofollow">
                   http://www.salumetandfriends.org
                  </a>
                  , especially Scientific Inquiry page. ETs have physically visited Earth in the past. Earths original pyramids were built by them, using THEIR methods (that we cant do), for purpose of producing energy to sustain them whilst here and to provide power for their return journey. There are those out there who are far in advance of us in what might be termed, for want of better expression, spiritual science.
                 </p>
                </div>
               </div>
              </li>
              <!-- #comment-## -->
              <li class="comment odd alt thread-odd thread-alt depth-1" id="dsq-comment-143385">
               <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-143385">
                <cite id="dsq-cite-143385">
                 http://www.facebook.com/people/Tyrone-Washington/100002776938421
                 <span id="dsq-author-user-143385">
                  Tyrone Washington
                 </span>
                </cite>
               </div>
               <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-143385">
                <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-143385">
                 <p>
                  What, are all of you still wishing upon planets?  Laughable.  You people have no idea of the realities of earth and life.  No idea at all.  You think everything just made itself out of nothing and poof!  Here we are, and therefore here other intelligent beings must be as well.
                 </p>
                 <p>
                  Pretty funny.  Why dont you tune in your receivers and listen to ET.  Whats that?  You have been doing exactly that for decades and. nothing!  Theres your answer, but you obviously dont like it.
                 </p>
                </div>
               </div>
              </li>

           <script type="text/javascript">
            /* &lt;![CDATA[ */
    var disqus_url = 'http://www.extremetech.com/extreme/152573-astronomers-estimate-100-billion-habitable-earth-like-planets-in-the-milky-way-50-sextillion-in-the-universe';
    var disqus_identifier = '152573 http://www.extremetech.com/?p=152573';
    var disqus_container_id = 'disqus_thread';
    var disqus_domain = 'disqus.com';
    var disqus_shortname = 'extremetech';
    var disqus_title = "Astronomers estimate 100 billion habitable Earth-like planets in the Milky Way, 50 sextillion in the universe";
        var disqus_config = function () {
        var config = this; // Access to the config object
        config.language = '';

        /*
           All currently supported events:
            * preData  fires just before we request for initial data
            * preInit - fires after we get initial data but before we load any dependencies
            * onInit  - fires when all dependencies are resolved but before dtpl template is rendered
            * afterRender - fires when template is rendered but before we show it
            * onReady - everything is done
         */

        config.callbacks.preData.push(function() {
            // clear out the container (its filled for SEO/legacy purposes)
            document.getElementById(disqus_container_id).innerHTML = '';
        });
                config.callbacks.onReady.push(function() {
            // sync comments in the background so we don't block the page
            var script = document.createElement('script');
            script.async = true;
            script.src = '?cf_action=sync_comments&amp;post_id=152573';

            var firstScript = document.getElementsByTagName( "script" )[0];
            firstScript.parentNode.insertBefore(script, firstScript);
        });
                    };
/* ]]&gt; */
           </script>
           <script type="text/javascript">
            /* &lt;![CDATA[ */
    var DsqLocal = {
        'trackbacks': [
        ],
        'trackback_url': "http:\/\/www.extremetech.com\/extreme\/152573-astronomers-estimate-100-billion-habitable-earth-like-planets-in-the-milky-way-50-sextillion-in-the-universe\/trackback"    };
/* ]]&gt; */
           </script>
           <script type="text/javascript">
            /* &lt;![CDATA[ */
(function() {
    var dsq = document.createElement('script'); dsq.type = 'text/javascript';
    dsq.async = true;
    dsq.src = '//' + disqus_shortname + '.' + 'disqus.com' + '/embed.js?pname=wordpress&amp;pver=2.74';
    (document.getElementsByTagName('head')[0] || document.getElementsByTagName('body')[0]).appendChild(dsq);
})();
/* ]]&gt; */
           </script>

       <div class="widget column widget_execphp" id="execphp-46">
        <script type="text/javascript">
         window._taboola = window._taboola || [];
    _taboola.push({flush: true});
    
    var __ZDTABEVENT = {
        accountid : "",
        init : function(acct) {
            __ZDTABEVENT.accountid = acct;
            var divs = document.querySelectorAll("div[id^=taboola]"), i=divs.length;
            while (i--) {
                divs[i].addEventListener("click", __ZDTABEVENT.clkevt);
                __ZDTABEVENT.track(divs[i].id, "imp");
            }
        },
        clkevt : function(evt){
            __ZDTABEVENT.track(evt.currentTarget.id, "clk");


        },
        track : function(id,evt) {
            var el = document.getElementById(id);
            var placement = el.getAttribute('data-placement');
            var pagetype = el.getAttribute('data-page-type');
            if(window.ga) window.ga('send', 'event', 'Taboola', pagetype + '-' + placement, evt);
            if(window._gaq) window._gaq.push(['_trackEvent', 'Taboola', pagetype+'-'+placement, evt, undefined, true]);
            if (__ZDDMP) { __ZDDMP.Event({signal:'taboola', pubid: __ZDTABEVENT.accountid, ptype:pagetype, placement:placement, evt:evt});}
        }
    };
    __ZDTABEVENT.init('ziffdavis-network15-extremetech');
        </script>
       </div>

         var _sf_async_config = _sf_async_config || {};
/** CONFIGURATION START **/
&lt;!-- set in head --&gt;
_sf_async_config.sections = 'Extreme'; 
_sf_async_config.authors ='Sebastian Anthony';
/** CONFIGURATION END **/
(function(){
function loadChartbeat()
{ window._sf_endpt=(new Date()).getTime(); var e = document.createElement('script'); e.setAttribute('language', 'javascript'); e.setAttribute('type', 'text/javascript'); e.setAttribute('src', '//static.chartbeat.com/js/chartbeat.js'); document.body.appendChild(e); }

var oldonload = window.onload;
window.onload = (typeof window.onload != 'function') ?
loadChartbeat : function()
{ oldonload(); loadChartbeat(); }

;
})();

         jQuery(document).ready(function() {
  setTimeout(function() {
  if (jQuery("#adsense").height() &lt; 8) { 
    if (window._gaq) { window._gaq.push(['_trackEvent', 'AdBlocker','Blocked' ,undefined, undefined, true]); }
    if (window.ga) { window.ga('send', 'event', 'AdBlocker', 'Blocked'); }
  } else {
    if (window._gaq) { window._gaq.push(['_trackEvent', 'AdBlocker','NotBlocked' ,undefined, undefined, true]); }
    if (window.ga) { window.ga('send', 'event', 'AdBlocker', 'NotBlocked' ); }
    }
	}, 2000);
});

  <script type="text/javascript">
   // &lt;![CDATA[
        var disqus_shortname = 'extremetech';
        (function () {
            var nodes = document.getElementsByTagName('span');
            for (var i = 0, url; i &lt; nodes.length; i++) {
                if (nodes[i].className.indexOf('dsq-postid') != -1) {
                    nodes[i].parentNode.setAttribute('data-disqus-identifier', nodes[i].getAttribute('rel'));
                    url = nodes[i].parentNode.href.split('#', 1);
                    if (url.length == 1) url = url[0];
                    else url = url[1]
                    nodes[i].parentNode.href = url + '#disqus_thread';
                }
            }
            var s = document.createElement('script'); s.async = true;
            s.type = 'text/javascript';
            s.src = '//' + 'disqus.com/forums/' + disqus_shortname + '/count.js';
            (document.getElementsByTagName('HEAD')[0] || document.getElementsByTagName('BODY')[0]).appendChild(s);
        }());
    //]]&gt;
  </script>
